report_title: Aircraft, Marine & Railroad Transportation Equipment Wholesaling in the US
executive_summary: The demand for wholesalers of aircraft, marine and railroad transportation equipment has experienced significant volatility. Still, economic expansion contributed to revenue growth during most of the period, as increased air travel and marine and railroad transportation encouraged sales of relevant equipment and supplies. The pandemic caused substantial disruption for the industry, with revenue declining 4.6% in 2020 alone. Subsequently, because of a recovering economy and reduction of travel restrictions, transportation demand rose – helping the industry resume expansion. Resilient economic growth has helped support equipment sales in recent years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Wholesalers have contended with heightened competition from original equipment manufacturer (OEM) distribution operations. These OEMs have offered a wider range of multiyear aftermarket services, like part replacements, to make their products more attractive to clients and to capture more of this profitable segment. Wholesalers have also had to contend with external competition from surplus dealers offering less expensive aircraft parts that had been stripped from older aircraft as new-generation aircraft entered service.

Boeing, a major buyer of aerospace equipment, has faced several issues in recent years that have impacted distributors. Canceled and delayed orders following 737 Max disasters and uncertainty caused by safety incidents have added to volatility in demand throughout the supply chain. The industry's connection to commodity markets and crude oil production leaves it vulnerable to significant shifts in revenue as prices rise or fall and production capacities adjust accordingly. The Aircraft, Marine and Railroad Transportation Equipment Wholesaling industry was particularly impacted by disruption from the pandemic.

Online sales for the industry are in high demand, making robust search engine optimization and user-friendly e-commerce crucial to growth. Boeing achieved an annual record for e-commerce parts sales in 2021, with over $2.0 billion generated by online orders that year.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Resilient economic growth is expected to support industry revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Continued economic expansion and growth in demand for transportation equipment is on track to support industry expansion in 2024.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Freight Transportation Services Index Will Continue to Track Demand for Wholesalers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The monthly measure of service volume from the for-hire transportation sector, the freight transportation services index, will remain a significant indicator of industry revenue growth. Typically, as freight activity increases, downstream customers like FedEx, UPS and DHL demand more substantial quantities of transportation equipment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: High Interest Rates May Hamper Industry Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Export sales will be negatively affected in the outlook period by persistent high interest rates. Elevated interest rates generally correlate with an appreciating US dollar thereby decreasing the purchasing power of foreign buyers, ultimately weakening exports. High interest rates will disincentivize capital investment among businesses, especially capital-intensive operations that rely on transportation equipment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Buyers Will Likely Continue to Seek Low-Cost Inputs When Possible
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Small industry companies will struggle as customers continue to source inventory from manufacturers directly to reduce purchase costs. Manufacturers and wholesalers will face increasing competition for an online presence, especially as businesses in this industry are increasingly relying on e-commerce sales activity.

industry_definition: This industry wholesales transportation equipment and supplies, including aircraft, aircraft parts and equipment, boats, marine equipment, railroad cars and railroad equipment. It doesn't wholesale marine pleasure craft engines and parts, motor vehicle-related transportation equipment or electronic navigational equipment (e.g. sonar or radar).

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Demand from air transportation

key_trends: Wholesalers with exclusive distribution rights can improve competitiveness. By being the only distributor for a product, a wholesaler can control supply and boost prices.

Wholesalers compete with divisions of large manufacturers or operations that only distribute the manufacturer's products. For manufacturers, having independent distribution cuts out intermediaries like wholesalers and facilitates more targeted quality control.
Wholesalers have contended with increased competition. Original equipment manufacturers have expanded their offering of aftermarket services to capture more of this profitable segment.

The freight transportation services index will remain a significant driver of industry revenue. Generally, as freight activity increases, downstream customers like FedEx, UPS and DHL demand more substantial quantities of transportation equipment.

The ongoing controversy with Boeing's safety incidents has added to volatility for wholesalers through its influence on aircraft equipment demand and supply. The company's decisions affect thousands of suppliers that rely on distributors for providing key inputs.

market_segmentation.segment: Businesses for end use in their own operation
market_segmentation.segment_description: These businesses include airline and freight companies buying components and equipment for their aircraft, ship and train fleets. As the pandemic recovery began, COVID-19 vaccines became available and business activity resumed. The economy improved and demand for air transportation increased due to eased travel restrictions, thereby boosting demand from these businesses.

Enterprises specialize in strictly wholesalers and distributors for resale to capture market share. Some manufacturers' distribution segments expand their reach by selling their parent company's products to independent distributors. Wholesalers that provide a larger selection of products but cannot access manufacturers often source their goods from competitors.

Manufacturers source from wholesalers to concentrate on final product assembly. Original equipment manufacturers source many of their parts and components from distributors. This practice enables them to focus more on the assembly of the final product rather than manufacturing smaller components.

Government agencies are increasing demand for aircraft and ships. The military is the single biggest buyer and holder of aircraft and ships, and therefore buys a significant portion of this industry's products. Rising tensions with China and Russia have boosted demand for defense spending, increasing demand for aircraft and ships.

market_segmentation.segment: Repair shops for use in repair work
market_segmentation.segment_description: The industry also serves demand for parts and equipment from repair shops for use in repair work, as well as retailers for resale and export sales. High interest rates, which generally correlate with an appreciating US dollar, reduced the purchasing power of foreign buyers – thereby weakening export sales.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Aircraft equipment and supplies including engines and parts
products_and_services.product_description: Aircraft equipment and supplies include fasteners, system components, electrical equipment and parts, cabin parts and furnishing and machined parts. Engine types vary from large jet engines to pistons and turboprops. Many of these products wear relatively quickly and require regular replacement to satisfy strict safety protocols and oversight, resulting in their large revenue share.

This category includes new and used boats, propulsion machinery, valves, hoses, pipes, electrical equipment and other marine-related parts and supplies. Since the Ship Building industry (IBISWorld report 33661a) is small relative to the aerospace industry, the proportion of marine-related products distribution to total transportation equipment distribution is also small.

This product segment includes railroad cars, equipment and supplies, subway cars and more. Increased demand for delivery services and logistics has increased demand for other transportation equipment, creating a waterfall effect that has benefited the industry overall.

While most industry wholesalers don't sell aircraft as their primary business, some do sell smaller, recreational aircraft to corporations and individuals. Demand for new aircraft is typically cyclical, given the relative age of an owned fleet and the need for updating.

tier_1_suppliers: Engine & Turbine Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Each year, the US government passes a discretionary budget that details proposed defense spending for the following year. The more funds the US Department of Defense has at its disposal, the more it can spend on equipment, supplies and parts for its aircraft and ships – increasing demand for industrial goods and services.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast and West regions comprise the largest proportions of industry establishments. This dominance is primarily the result of the high concentration of downstream industries in these regions. Many military bases, especially naval facilities, are located in these areas.
The Southeast and West regions comprise the largest proportions of industry establishments. This dominance is primarily the result of the high concentration of downstream industries in these regions.
The majority of locations in the Southwest region are in Texas. Texas is a major aerospace and airline hub, attracting wholesalers of many aircraft, marine and railroad transportation equipment.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FAA provides guidance regulations for aircraft parts distribution to ensure safe and reliable aircraft operation. While this might boost administrative costs, larger clients (like airlines) will only source their parts from accredited suppliers.

Most of the products sold by distributors that the original manufacturer didn't produce must meet parts manufacturer approval. PMA parts and their manufacturers meet specific quality criteria to be used on aircraft. Original manufacturers also must abide by similar rules. It's essential that distributors only purchase parts that are approved.

The ASA is a not-for-profit association representing more than 760 global member companies. These members collectively lead critical logistics programs, purchasing efforts and the global distribution of aircraft parts. The ASA-100 accreditation is provided to qualified distributors by ASA. To receive accreditation, wholesalers must meet ASA-100 standards for product care, inventory management, parts tracking, self-audits and environmental procedures.

The IAQG sets the standards for quality within the worldwide aerospace industry supply chain. Most wholesalers can benefit from obtaining the AS9120 quality management system certification for stockist distributors by IAQG, intended to ensure high-quality aerospace products. Requirements involve supply chain transparency, inventory control and documentation.
The DFARS regulates everything from the distributor's inventory management and tracking to how it treats its employees. Distributors must also abide by laws dictating what and to whom they can sell.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry assistance level is low and steady.
The competition level is high and steady.

factors_decreased_barrier: The globalization level is low but increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Wholesalers with exclusive distribution rights can improve competitiveness. By being the only distributor for a product, a wholesaler can control supply and boost prices.

Wholesalers compete with divisions of large manufacturers or operations that only distribute the manufacturer's products. For manufacturers, having independent distribution cuts out intermediaries like wholesalers and facilitates more targeted quality control.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is composed of many small to medium-size companies. Despite consolidation among the industry's most prominent wholesalers, the industry remains highly fragmented.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Economies of scale for large wholesalers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large wholesalers reap the benefits of economies of scale. They offer a wide selection of products and, in some cases, have exclusive distribution rights to certain manufacturers' goods. They can leverage their large size to negotiate lower purchase prices and pass these savings to customers. Their economies of scale also enable them to boost efficiency and profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases account for the majority of industry expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Most purchase costs for this industry are allocated toward inventory purchases since the equipment and supplies are costly and require specialized transportation and storage.
Wholesalers rely on labor for customer service, sales and marketing, in addition to the delivery of aircraft, marine and railroad transportation

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Input Prices Put a Strain on Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Higher raw material prices, like those for steel and aluminum, have strained the profit of aircraft equipment wholesalers (the industry's largest source of revenue). However, increased demand for air transportation has helped keep profits stable, leading to a rise in profit in the current period.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Aircraft, marine and railroad transportation equipment are organized, stored and shipped using labor. While computer systems are designed to monitor inventory levels and track sales, each step requires significant labor.
The need for significant capex to prepare facilities to maintain inventories, upgrade technology, and manage logistic operations is a major hurdle for new entrants.

volatility_points.volatility_title: ECONOMIC CONDITIONS CAN INFLUENCE WHOLESALERS' SUCCESS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Recessions reduce spending, therefore in the event of a recession or economic downturn demand for aircraft, marine and railroad transportation equipment will likely drop. High interest rates also negatively impact wholesalers since they make purchasing capital more expensive, which can constrain business activity.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Manufacturing Isn't Immune to Global Economic and Pricing Trends
volatility_points.volatility_description: Because of the reliance on commodities as input costs to building aircraft, marine and railroad transportation equipment, upstream manufacturing industries are susceptible to worldwide shifts in the prices of semiconductors, utilities and more.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: TECHNOLOGY HAS HELPED MODERNIZE AIRCRAFT, MARINE AND RAILROAD TRANSPORTATION EQUIPMENT WHOLESALING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Wholesalers can manage inventory more efficiently by integrating distribution management software radio-frequency identification (RFID). Wholesalers that integrate new technology can often more rapidly adapt to changes in consumer demand.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: TECHNOLOGY HAS HELPED MODERNIZE AIRCRAFT, MARINE AND RAILROAD TRANSPORTATION EQUIPMENT WHOLESALING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Merchant wholesalers can benefit from product innovation at the manufacturing level by quickly stocking up on new items as they become available.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: TECHNOLOGY HAS HELPED MODERNIZE AIRCRAFT, MARINE AND RAILROAD TRANSPORTATION EQUIPMENT WHOLESALING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Online services that enable customers to search inventory lists, check pricing, place and print orders and access online billing have improved accessibility, reliability and efficiency.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any one market, major customer or other isolated revenue stream?
FAQs.answer: Commercial and military aircraft use account for a significant portion of industry revenue. Aircraft manufacturers also represent a large market.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in such a crowded industry?
FAQs.answer: Companies specialize in large markets such as aircraft parts. Companies specialize in niche markets such as marine parts (less competition, yet lower sales volume).

FAQs.question: How do you manage volatile demand that results from economic conditions or seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Inventory levels are managed to reduce overstock. Volatile demand stems from volatile commodities such as crude oil prices.

FAQs.question: How does your company negotiate favorable purchase costs with suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Companies typically rely on networking within industry associations. regulations on behalf of members. The Aviation Suppliers Association also provides similar services in addition to various accreditations. Favorable purchase costs depend on the reputation and size of the operation.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology into the purchasing process to make buying more efficient for customers?
FAQs.answer: Technology companies use inventory management systems to better handle orders. Using such technologies allows for customers to get their items faster.

FAQs.question: Does your company currently have an e-commerce platform for volume sales? If not, do you have plans to create one?
FAQs.answer: Technology companies now integrate their inventory management with their websites. Website databases allow customers to find products faster; therefore more companies in this industry are adopting them.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor potential changes to the regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: Compliance companies join industry associations or consultants. It is important for companies in this industry to anticipate declines in the airline industry.

FAQs.question: How have you adjusted to new regulations over the past decade? How have you handled compliance costs?
FAQs.answer: Compliance regulations have been sparse; however, regulations imposed on the airline industry may affect demand for this industry. Compliance costs are low for this industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer customers access to trade credit? If so, what measures are in place to ensure customers pay back on time?
FAQs.answer: Typically, reputation and size determine credibility and therefore credit terms. Smaller, newer customers may be subject to higher rates or not extended credit terms at all (although this is rare).

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected your purchase costs and selling prices over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: The price of jet fuel can affect this industry. However, it will take a large increase to negatively affect this industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company provide after-sales advice to customers? Do you generate revenue through accessory sales?
FAQs.answer: Superior after-sales service develops a relationship between the wholesaler and the customer, providing an additional avenue of accessory sales revenue.

FAQs.question: Do your potential hires need to have past knowledge of the product? How do you ensure that all staff are thoroughly knowledgeable about the products?
FAQs.answer: Product knowledge enables wholesalers to sell products that best suit the needs of the client. Proximity to key markets enables wholesalers to provide additional services, such as installation and maintenance.
